newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: NZ sheepmeat exports near record highs - Meat Board. [CORRECTED 23:00 GMT]
newsitem.headline: NZ sheepmeat exports near record highs - Meat Board. [CORRECTED 23:00 GMT]

text.p: Returns for New Zealand sheepmeat exports are nearing record levels, New Zealand Meat Board chairman John Acland said on Thursday.

Acland said that sheepmeat exports earned by New Zealand companies earned NZ$428.2 million in the quarter ended June 30, 1996, an increase of NZ$86.1 million (corrects from NZ$153.8 million) on the same period last year.
"The $400 million level has only been exceeded twice before," Acland said in a statement.
"The first time was back in 1992, when the figure peaked at NZ$429.9 million. The following year it reached NZ$428.4 million, a similar figure to the latest quarter."
He said farmers would be encouraged by the "dramatic" increase in value per tonne for sheepmeat.
"Sheepmeat, at $3,780 per tonne, is now returning over $1,000 more per tonne than beef. Four to five years ago the opposite was true.
"Beef peaked at $5,070 per tonne back in the last quarter of 1989 when sheepmeats were at $2,770 per tonne."
Acland said sheepmeats, especially lamb, looked set to reach new heights, whereas beef prices were unlikely to improve very much in the next few quarters.

"The higher added value being attained by New Zealand exporters from chilled and further processed products as well as substantially higher prices in the main markets of Europe, North America and the Middle East accounts for the rise in value/volume for New Zealand sheepmeat.
Acland said despite the rise of the New Zealand dollar, the NZ dollar/tonne return had been rising steadily for the past two years. -- Wellington newsroom 64 4 4734 746
